_decoded_content.title: Airflow 2.1.2 daemon flag & configuration file bug
_decoded_content.description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.

If you are submitting an issue with a tap, please include:

- account details
- target details
- entities selected  with meltano select (if you have selected any entities), as the bug may be related to a specific entity
- the full elt command you are running
- full output of the meltano elt command. Logs can get pretty long, so you can add the full log as a snippet in the Meltano project and add a link in the issue.
--->

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
1. When trying to start an Airflow Scheduler Instance with `meltano invoke airflow scheduler -D` and/or `meltano invoke airflow scheduler --daemon`. However, despite producing a normal CLI output... you'll see a 'scheduler does not have a heartbeat' warning message. Currently the only was to remove this warning message and produce a 'heartbeat' is to run  `meltano invoke airflow scheduler` and leave the terminal window open. 
2. Currently we are trying to set the Airflow configurations to match the following:

      a. executor = LocalExecutor

      b. sql_alchemy_conn = postgresql

However these should be set in the `airflow.cfg`, under the path `.meltano/run/airflow` There are not the correct files... Currently it only host the files; airflow-scheduler.err, airflow-scheduler.log, airflow-scheduler.out, and webserver_config.py


### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
1. `airflow.cfg` should be located under the path and `.meltano/run/airflow`. However this file is not always present and seems to me removed and sporadically reproduced overwriting any previous airflow configurations applied using environmental variables.



### Steps to reproduce
1. Open a meltano project directory
2. Run `meltano invoke airflow scheduler -D` or `meltano invoke airflow scheduler --daemon`
3. Open the Airflow UI


- Meltano version (output with `meltano --version`)
- 1.102.0

- Airflow Configurations (output with `airflow info`)
- apache-airflow-providers-ftp         | 2.0.0
- apache-airflow-providers-http       | 2.0.0
- apache-airflow-providers-imap      | 2.0.0
- apache-airflow-providers-slack      | 4.0.0
- apache-airflow-providers-sqlite     | 2.0.0


### Relevant logs and/or screenshots
1. Run `meltano invoke airflow scheduler -D` or `meltano invoke airflow scheduler --daemon`
2. Open the Airflow UI


![Screen_Shot_2022-05-24_at_9.07.27_AM](/uploads/3cfaae61b0530c2a39da605db925923a/Screen_Shot_2022-05-24_at_9.07.27_AM.png)

1. Configure Airflow using the `meltano.yml` file

      a. `meltano config airflow set core.executor LocalExecutor`

      b. `meltano config airflow set core.sql_alchemy_conn postgresql://airflow:vegqwesdef@ec2-34-222-99-188.us-west-2.compute.amazonaws.com:5432/airflow`

![Screen_Shot_2022-05-25_at_10.41.30_AM](/uploads/4d956147908ba7067d009e55a102674d/Screen_Shot_2022-05-25_at_10.41.30_AM.png)



### Possible fixes
Determine how airflow.cfg is created by the Meltano project.

_decoded_content.title: Add cron as `orchestrator` plugin
_decoded_content.description:
For simple meltano deployments, it would be great to have a cron-based orchestrator using the `meltano schedule` configuration, without having to set-up an Airflow instance with a db, users, etc.

The meltano UI already makes it possible to manually run meltano schedules, so this would be a nice complement :smile:

_decoded_content.title: `meltano config airflow` fails for newly install Airflow plugin
_decoded_content.description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.

If you are submitting an issue with a tap, please include:

- account details
- target details
- entities selected  with meltano select (if you have selected any entities), as the bug may be related to a specific entity
- the full elt command you are running
- full output of the meltano elt command. Logs can get pretty long, so you can add the full log as a snippet in the Meltano project and add a link in the issue.
--->

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
_What is happening now?_

When running `meltano config airflow` to print the current Airflow configuration, the command fails with the following error:

```bash
[Errno 2] No such file or directory: '/Users/kp/Projects/squared/data/.meltano/run/airflow/airflow.cfg'
```

Once `meltano invoke airflow webserver` has been run once, the missing file is created and the command succeeds in printing the current config.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
_What should be happening?_

`meltano config airflow` should be able to print the current Airflow configuration regardless of the existence of Meltano-managed files.


### Steps to reproduce
_How one can reproduce the issue?_

```bash
meltano init airflow_bug

meltano add orchestrator airflow

meltano install

meltano config airflow
```

I am somewhat surprised that `meltano install` is necessary as `meltano config airflow` is just supposed to print the current config 🤔

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots
_Please use code blocks (\`\`\`) to format console output_


### Workaround

As a workaround, a user can run `meltano invoke airflow webserver`, which should fully initialize the airflow resources and prevent the error from triggering.


### Possible fixes
_If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem or suggest a fix_



### Further regression test
_Ensure we automatically catch similar issues in the future_

- [ ] Write additional adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

_decoded_content.title: Jobs canceled via Airflow may not be properly aborted in logs
_decoded_content.description:
Following from a slack conversation, it seems Airflow is killing jobs too quickly or in a way that does not allow Meltano to mark jobs as canceled/failed. This is leaving job logs in a state that may require users to use `--force` when trying to rerun.

More info in slack thread: https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01TCRBBJD7/p1650393919971169?thread_ts=1650299838.276379&cid=C01TCRBBJD7

> First, we should probably check Airflow wrappers to see if the behavior of its job canceling (SIGTERM) is not properly shutting down meltano is an exception or the norm. Perhaps there are specific conditions that cause the job abort to not be logged? As noted:
>
> > My concern is when a task is stopped in airflow the metlano is not shutting down properly

_decoded_content.title: Consider validating interval expressions when scheduling jobs
_decoded_content.description:
Right now when you schedule a job via the CLI, no input validation of specified intervals is performed. We're reliant on the schedule validating the interval and then surfacing issues to the user some how:

```shell
(melty-3.8) ➜  run-dev2 meltano schedule gitlab-to-json-stuff4 tap-gitlab target-json "stuff"
Scheduled 'gitlab-to-json-stuff4' at stuff

(melty-3.8) ➜  run-dev2 meltano schedule list
[@daily] gitlab-to-json-daily: tap-gitlab → target-jsonl x transforms
[5 4 * * *] gitlab-to-json-stuff: tap-gitlab → target-jsonl x transforms
[*/5 4 * * *] gitlab-to-json-another: tap-gitlab → target-jsonl x transforms
[stuff] gitlab-to-json-stuff4: tap-gitlab → target-json x transforms
```

[In slack](https://meltano.slack.com/archives/CKHP6G5V4/p1644520257808579?thread_ts=1644519607.344569&cid=CKHP6G5V4) it was mentioned that this was initially an intentional choice since Airflow supports a few different formats. 

Looks like vanilla cron syntax validation might be acceptable:

- [Airflow expects](https://airflow.apache.org/docs/apache-airflow/1.10.1/scheduler.html#dag-runs) a standard cron syntax or *nix style cron alias (`*/5 * * * *`, or `@hourly`) , plus "none" and "@once".
- [Dagster expects](https://docs.dagster.io/concepts/partitions-schedules-sensors/schedules#a-basic-schedule) standard cron syntax.

@aaronsteers mentioned in slack that we could potentially start validating but supply a cli arg for folks to use if they want to skip validation on the meltano side and instead rely on the scheduler.

_decoded_content.title: Make Airflow invoke errors more informative
_decoded_content.description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.

If you are submitting an issue with a tap, please include:

- account details
- target details
- entities selected  with meltano select (if you have selected any entities), as the bug may be related to a specific entity
- the full elt command you are running
- full output of the meltano elt command. Logs can get pretty long, so you can add the full log as a snippet in the Meltano project and add a link in the issue.
--->

### What is the current *bug* behavior?
_What is happening now?_

Invoking Airflow triggers the `initdb`/`db init`, which raises an exception on failure but it's not very informative about what's causing the command to fail.

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?
_What should be happening?_

Apart from the ``Airflow metadata database could not be initialized: `airflow initdb` failed`` message, Meltano should output the underlying exception causing the database initialization to fail.

### Steps to reproduce
_How one can reproduce the issue?_

Some users have seen this error when there is a missing dependency like `psycopg2` (https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01TCRBBJD7/p1633708210429000?thread_ts=1633596190.400300&cid=C01TCRBBJD7).

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots
_Please use code blocks (\`\`\`) to format console output_

```
$ meltano invoke airflow run
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/Users/finn/Library/Python/3.8/lib/python/site-packages/meltano/cli/__init__.py", line 52, in main
    raise CliError(str(err)) from err
meltano.cli.utils.CliError: Airflow metadata database could not be initialized: `airflow initdb` failed
Airflow metadata database could not be initialized: `airflow initdb` failed
```

### Possible fixes
_If you can, link to the line of code that might be responsible for the problem or suggest a fix_

- More details could be added to the `AsyncSubprocessError` exception in https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/blob/master/src/meltano/core/plugin/airflow.py#L121-125.

### Further regression test
_Ensure we automatically catch similar issues in the future_

- [ ] Write additional adequate test cases and submit test results
- [ ] Test results should be reviewed by a person from the team

milestone.title: Backlog
milestone.description:
As a start, I think it would be good to prioritize based on:
- urgency of getting feedback
- relative implementation difficulty
- symbiotic relationships between issues

_decoded_content.title: Support Airflow webserver base URL as a known setting
_decoded_content.description:
From Slack: https://meltano.slack.com/archives/C01TCRBBJD7/p1633464692374100

It'd be useful for some people to declare the base URL for the Airflow Webserver directly in `meltano.yml`. Something like

```yaml
plugins:
  orchestrators:
    - name: airflow
      config:
        webserver.base_url: https://my-meltano-server:8080
```

_decoded_content.title: Add a `ui` command for the `Airflow` plugin
_decoded_content.description:
The Airflow plugin definition does not have any pre-defined commands built. Would be nice to add a `ui` command which just quickly launches the web GUI.

Something like...

```yml
    commands: 
      ui:
         executable: airflow
         args: webserver --port 8080
```

which would go here: https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/blob/master/src%2Fmeltano%2Fcore%2Fbundle%2Fdiscovery.yml#L2531

_decoded_content.title: Configurable webserver_config.py for Airflow 2 in Meltano
_decoded_content.description:
## Background

HackerOne needs to be able to add OKTA as a custom Oauth provider to the Airflow 2 webserver. A way to achieve this is to modify the `webserver_config.py` and add an Oauth provider there. 

We are currently achieving this by committing this file in the repository
```
.meltano/run/airflow/webserver_config.py
```

The downsides of this approach are:

1. The `.meltano` folder is a system/ignored folder, so it feels strange that one file in there is not ignored
1. The `run` folder is cleared when installing on a clean system which requires restoring the file afterwards

## Solution

A solution was proposed on Slack (https://meltano.slack.com/archives/CQUDGG7U2/p1614010295010000?thread_ts=1613847594.009300&cid=CQUDGG7U2):

> Meltano could support orchestrate/webserver_config.py out of the box and handle copying it itself

_decoded_content.title: Consider creating an Airflow operator and adding it to Astronomer Registry
_decoded_content.description:
It would be nice for discoverability to have an Airflow operator listed on Astronomer Registry like https://registry.astronomer.io/providers/fivetran/modules/fivetranoperator or https://registry.astronomer.io/providers/airbyte/modules/airbytetriggersyncoperator. 

The operator could directly run `meltano elt` by building on the `DockerOperator`, or it could trigger a sync in an externally running Meltano UI once we have https://gitlab.com/meltano/meltano/-/issues/2813.

This would be very different from our Airflow integration, which has Meltano manage Airflow and automatically create DAGs for scheduled pipelines. Running Meltano inside a custom Airflow DAG is valid as well, of course.

cc @tayloramurphy

_decoded_content.title: Dagster as orchestrator
_decoded_content.description:
### Problem to solve
Add support for more orchestrators to improve the options for adoption of Meltano in a production context.

### Target audience
Organizations and data teams that have already invested in an orchestrator other than Airflow.

### Further details
I am considering setting up Meltano for use at my day job, and I currently use Dagster as my workflow
orchestrator so I was curious where in the code I should look to see about adding support for that integration. Also, if you have any pointers about sharp edges that I should avoid, or any upcoming change in the structure or roadmap of the project that would be helpful.

### Proposal
I would like to be able to use Dagster as the orchestrator for executing my Meltano pipelines.

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?
Success looks like having a well defined integration with Dagster such that I can easily get up and running with Meltano as a component in a pipeline when I am already using the Dagster/Dagit service in my environment. The likely path is to add a plugin along the lines of what has been built for Great Expectations or DBT so that I can define a "[Solid](https://docs.dagster.io/overview/solids-pipelines/solids)" that will execute a Meltano pipeline definition and provide detailed output that integrates with the existing logging infrastructure. If it is possible to use the Dagster table space as the metadata storage for Meltano for a tighter and simpler deployment, that would be a stretch goal to work toward.
